stem: A baseball catcher develops weakness in finger abduction after sustaining a fracture of the hook of the hamate. Sensation over the dorsal ulnar hand is intact, but grip strength is reduced. Which branch of the ulnar nerve is most likely injured?

choices.A: Deep motor branch of the ulnar nerve
choices.B: Superficial sensory branch of the ulnar nerve
choices.C: Dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve

rationale_correct: Hook of hamate fractures commonly injure the deep motor branch of the ulnar nerve in Guyon canal, causing intrinsic hand weakness with preserved dorsoulnar sensation.

rationale_distractors.B: Superficial sensory injury would impair medial palm sensation without significant motor loss.
rationale_distractors.C: The dorsal cutaneous branch leaves proximal to the wrist; damage would reduce dorsal sensation, which is intact here.
rationale_distractors.D: The medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve supplies forearm sensation rather than intrinsic hand muscles.
rationale_distractors.E: Posterior interosseous nerve lesions cause finger extension weakness and spare ulnar-innervated interossei.
